content:
It's great that you have a new bike shop nearby. Supporting local businesses is always a good idea, and it's even better when they're passionate about cycling.

Before you take your bike in, consider calling the shop to ask a few questions:

* Do they have experience with road bikes and the specific components on your bike?
* What's their typical turnaround time for a tune-up or service?
* Do they offer any package deals or discounts for charity ride participants?
* Can they provide you with a detailed estimate of the work and costs involved?

This will help you get a sense of their expertise and what to expect from the service. Additionally, it's a good idea to ask if they have any recommendations for preparing your bike for the charity ride.

When you drop off your bike, be sure to:

* Provide any relevant information about your bike, such as its make, model, and any recent issues you've experienced.
* Ask the mechanic to inspect the bike thoroughly and provide a detailed report of any work needed.
* Discuss any upgrades or accessories you're interested in, such as new tires or a bike computer.

By being prepared and asking the right questions, you'll be able to get your road bike serviced efficiently and effectively, ensuring you're ready to roll for the charity ride.
